title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: My name is Aish K

gf_histogram(~price, data = diamonds) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 1A: Diamond Prices",
    caption = "ggformula"
  )









diamonds %>% 
  gf_histogram(~price, bins = 100) %>% 
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 1B: Diamond Prices",
    caption = "ggformula"

  )











There are a great many diamonds at relatively low prices, but there are a good few diamonds at very high prices too.
Using a high number of bins does not materially change the view of the histogram.


diamonds %>% 
  gf_histogram(~carat) %>% 
  gf_labs(
     title = "Plot 2A: Carats of Diamonds",
    caption = "ggformula"
  )









diamonds %>% 
  gf_histogram(~carat, bins = 100) %>% 
  gf_labs(
     title = "Plot 2B: Carats of Diamonds",
    caption = "ggformula"
  )












there is a marked “discreteness” to the distribution. Some values of carat are far more common than others. For example, 1, 1.5, and 2 carat diamonds are large in number.


diamonds %>% 
  gf_histogram(~price, fill = ~cut) %>% 
  gf_labs(
     title = "Plot 3A: Diamond Prices", caption = "ggformula")









diamonds %>%
  gf_histogram(~price, fill = ~cut, color = "black", alpha = 0.3) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 3B: Prices by Cut",
    caption = "ggformula"
  )









diamonds %>%
  gf_histogram(~price, fill = ~cut, color = "black", alpha = 0.3) %>%
  gf_facet_wrap(~cut) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 3C: Prices by Filled and Facetted by Cut",
    caption = "ggformula"
  ) %>%
  gf_theme(theme(
    axis.text.x = element_text(
      angle = 45,
      hjust = 1
    )
  ))









diamonds %>%
  gf_histogram(~price, fill = ~cut, color = "black", alpha = 0.3) %>%
  gf_facet_wrap(~cut, scales = "free_y", nrow = 2) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 3D: Prices Filled and Facetted by Cut",
    subtitle = "Free y-scale",
    caption = "ggformula"
  ) %>%
  gf_theme(theme(
    axis.text.x =
      element_text(
        angle = 45,
        hjust = 1
      )
  ))

# Demo purposes only!

race_start_factor <- race_df %>%
  filter(distance == 0) %>% # Races that actually took place
  mutate(
    start_day_time =
      case_when(
        start_time > hms("02:00:00") &
          start_time <= hms("06:00:00") ~ "early_morning",
        start_time > hms("06:00:01") &
          start_time <= hms("10:00:00") ~ "late_morning",
        start_time > hms("10:00:01") &
          start_time <= hms("14:00:00") ~ "mid_day",
        start_time > hms("14:00:01") &
          start_time <= hms("18:00:00") ~ "afternoon",
        start_time > hms("18:00:01") &
          start_time <= hms("22:00:00") ~ "evening",
        start_time > hms("22:00:01") &
          start_time <= hms("23:59:59") ~ "night",
        start_time >= hms("00:00:00") &
          start_time <= hms("02:00:00") ~ "postmidnight",
        .default = "other"
      )
  ) %>%
  mutate(
    start_day_time =
      as_factor(start_day_time) %>%
        fct_collapse(
          .f = .,
          night = c("night", "postmidnight")
        )
  )

Warning: There was 1 warning in `mutate()`.
ℹ In argument: `start_day_time = `%>%`(...)`.
Caused by warning:
! Unknown levels in `f`: night

##
# Join with rank_df
race_start_factor %>%
  left_join(rank_df, by = "race_year_id") %>%
  drop_na(time_in_seconds) %>%
  gf_histogram(
    ~time_in_seconds,
    bins = 75,
    fill = ~start_day_time,
    color = ~start_day_time,
    alpha = 0.5
  ) %>%
  gf_facet_wrap(vars(start_day_time), ncol = 2, scales = "free_y") %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Race Times by Start-Time")

title: Day-4
text:
We have downloaded a new library today - “crosstable”. It is used for fast stats for multiple variables in table form.

library(tidyverse)

gf_histogram(~price, data = diamonds) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 1A: Diamond Prices",
    caption = "ggformula"
  )









diamonds %>% 
  gf_histogram(~price, bins = 100) %>% 
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 1B: Diamond Prices",
    caption = "ggformula"

  )











There are a great many diamonds at relatively low prices, but there are a good few diamonds at very high prices too.
Using a high number of bins does not materially change the view of the histogram.


diamonds %>% 
  gf_histogram(~carat) %>% 
  gf_labs(
     title = "Plot 2A: Carats of Diamonds",
    caption = "ggformula"
  )









diamonds %>% 
  gf_histogram(~carat, bins = 100) %>% 
  gf_labs(
     title = "Plot 2B: Carats of Diamonds",
    caption = "ggformula"
  )












there is a marked “discreteness” to the distribution. Some values of carat are far more common than others. For example, 1, 1.5, and 2 carat diamonds are large in number.


diamonds %>% 
  gf_histogram(~price, fill = ~cut) %>% 
  gf_labs(
     title = "Plot 3A: Diamond Prices", caption = "ggformula")









diamonds %>%
  gf_histogram(~price, fill = ~cut, color = "black", alpha = 0.3) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 3B: Prices by Cut",
    caption = "ggformula"
  )









diamonds %>%
  gf_histogram(~price, fill = ~cut, color = "black", alpha = 0.3) %>%
  gf_facet_wrap(~cut) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 3C: Prices by Filled and Facetted by Cut",
    caption = "ggformula"
  ) %>%
  gf_theme(theme(
    axis.text.x = element_text(
      angle = 45,
      hjust = 1
    )
  ))









diamonds %>%
  gf_histogram(~price, fill = ~cut, color = "black", alpha = 0.3) %>%
  gf_facet_wrap(~cut, scales = "free_y", nrow = 2) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 3D: Prices Filled and Facetted by Cut",
    subtitle = "Free y-scale",
    caption = "ggformula"
  ) %>%
  gf_theme(theme(
    axis.text.x =
      element_text(
        angle = 45,
        hjust = 1
      )
  ))

# Demo purposes only!

race_start_factor <- race_df %>%
  filter(distance == 0) %>% # Races that actually took place
  mutate(
    start_day_time =
      case_when(
        start_time > hms("02:00:00") &
          start_time <= hms("06:00:00") ~ "early_morning",
        start_time > hms("06:00:01") &
          start_time <= hms("10:00:00") ~ "late_morning",
        start_time > hms("10:00:01") &
          start_time <= hms("14:00:00") ~ "mid_day",
        start_time > hms("14:00:01") &
          start_time <= hms("18:00:00") ~ "afternoon",
        start_time > hms("18:00:01") &
          start_time <= hms("22:00:00") ~ "evening",
        start_time > hms("22:00:01") &
          start_time <= hms("23:59:59") ~ "night",
        start_time >= hms("00:00:00") &
          start_time <= hms("02:00:00") ~ "postmidnight",
        .default = "other"
      )
  ) %>%
  mutate(
    start_day_time =
      as_factor(start_day_time) %>%
        fct_collapse(
          .f = .,
          night = c("night", "postmidnight")
        )
  )

Warning: There was 1 warning in `mutate()`.

Caused by warning:
! Unknown levels in `f`: night

# Join with rank_df
race_start_factor %>%
  left_join(rank_df, by = "race_year_id") %>%
  drop_na(time_in_seconds) %>%
  gf_histogram(
    ~time_in_seconds,
    bins = 75,
    fill = ~start_day_time,
    color = ~start_day_time,
    alpha = 0.5
  ) %>%
  gf_facet_wrap(vars(start_day_time), ncol = 2, scales = "free_y") %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Race Times by Start-Time")

taxi_modified <- taxi %>%
  mutate(
    dow = factor(dow,
      levels = c("Mon", "Tue", "Wed", "Thu", "Fri", "Sat", "Sun"),
      labels = c("Mon", "Tue", "Wed", "Thu", "Fri", "Sat", "Sun"),
      ordered = TRUE
    ),
    ##
    local = factor(local,
      levels = c("no", "yes"),
      labels = c("no", "yes"),
      ordered = TRUE
    ),
    ##
    month = factor(month,
      levels = c("Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr"),
      labels = c("Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr"),
      ordered = TRUE
    )
  )
taxi_modified %>% glimpse()

gf_bar(~tip, data = taxi_modified) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 1A: Counts of Tips")

  gf_bar(~tip,
    fill = ~local,
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 2A: Bar Chart")

  gf_bar(~tip,
    fill = ~local,
    position = "stack"
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 2A: Stacked Bar Chart")

  gf_bar(~tip,
    fill = ~local,
    position = "dodge"
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 2A: Dodged Bar Chart")

  gf_bar(~tip,
    fill = ~local,
    position = "fill"
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 2A: Dodged Bar Chart")

  gf_bar(~company,
    fill = ~tip,
    position = "fill"
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 2D: Filled Bar Chart",
    subtitle = "Shows Per group differences in Proportions!"
  )

  gf_bar(~hour,
    fill = ~tip,
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot B: Counts of Tips by Hour"

  gf_bar(~dow,
    fill = ~tip,
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot C: Counts of Tips by Day of Week"
  )

  gf_bar(~month,
    fill = ~tip
  ) %>% 
  gf_labs( title = "Plot D: Counts of Tips by Month")

  gf_bar(~month | dow,
    fill = ~tip
  ) %>% 
  gf_labs( title = "Plot D: Counts of Tips by day of week and month")

  gf_bar(~dow | hour,
    fill = ~tip
  ) %>%

    )

  gf_bar(~dow | hour,
    fill = ~tip,
    position = "fill"
  ) %>% 
  gf_labs( 
    title = "Plot F: Counts of Tips by Hour and Day of Week",
    subtitle = "Is this plot arrangement easy to grasp?"
    )
